14.text:
Can imagination and art
bring us closer to truth than science?

21.text:
so I was raised on a diet
of empiricism, rationalism, and reason,

27.text:
the bedrocks of knowledge,
or so I thought.

31.text: Until I strayed from science a bit,

33.text:
and had a little fling
with writing fiction.

36.text:
And that fling turned into something
a little more long-term,

41.text:
And, in this process,
something shifted in me.

45.text:
And it seemed to me,
and it seems to me now, that science,

51.text: with its focused beam of objectivity,

54.text:
excludes what's in the periphery,
the less tangible aspects of life.

60.text:
And art has a wonderful way
of bringing these elements into relief.

65.text: Let me give you an example of what I mean.

68.text:
I received some feedback on a new novel
I'd been working on recently.

71.text:
And it turns out I'd made
a classic mistake.

74.text: I had written a passive protagonist.

76.text: My main character had no agency.

79.text:
Now, readers intuitively know
that this is unrealistic.

83.text:
A character cannot be passive
to the drama unfolding around him,

86.text: simply because it's not true to life.

89.text:
And here is where literature
unveils a deeper truth:

93.text:
that agency is an essential ingredient
of the human experience.

98.text:
We need to know that we can take action
and effect change in our lives.

104.text:
If this is missing from a book,
it will lead to loss of interest.

107.text:
If this is missing from a life,
it will lead to despair.

112.text:
But this essential truth
is forgotten in, of all places,

118.text: As a doctor, I work in an environment

120.text:
that is essentially designed
as a really badly written novel.

124.text:
Passive protagonists abound,
thanks to me and my colleagues,

127.text:
who educate patients to give up
their agency and to submit to their care.

133.text:
Whether they're being asked
to accept a diagnosis,

138.text:
or to swallow the tablets
placed before them.

141.text:
Patient passivity is a byproduct
of the new healthcare paradigm.

147.text:
And I see this,
the removal of patient agency,

150.text:
as one of the most disturbing
new realities of conventional medicine.

156.text: Well, it's clear how we got here.

159.text:
We got here
because medicine is not an art

161.text:
that deals with the soul
of human experience;

164.text:
medicine is a science,
and it deals in the mechanics of illness.

168.text:
And if science were to have
a slogan, it would be,

171.text:
"Science: if it isn't matter,
it doesn't matter."

176.text: Clearly, in this sort of paradigm,

178.text:
fluffy concepts like personal
agency have no role.

183.text:
At this point in our cultural evolution,
science has become the alpha male.

188.text:
It muscles its worldview around
as the only one worth respecting.

194.text:
science has dominated,
and art pushed to the fringes.

197.text:
And it has left us
with this very lopsided dichotomy,

202.text:
which is more important than art,
which is about imagination.

206.text:
Science studies the physical world,
the world of proof and certainty,

212.text:
which plays in the space
of the ephemeral and the uncertain.

219.text:
whereas art
simply experiences the Universe.

223.text: Now medicine, as a scientific discipline,

226.text:
of course must obey
that matter-based mantra.

230.text:
And of course, it has also
brought us a very long way.

232.text: It has brought us a clear understanding

234.text:
of the cellular and molecular
mechanisms of the body,

238.text:
and it has enabled life-saving treatments,
both pharmaceutical and surgical.

244.text: But the hard mechanics of this paradigm

247.text:
continue to push
the soft ephemera to the sidelines.

251.text:
And this has resulted in a separation
between our true sense of self,

255.text:
that nebulous sense of personal identity
that doesn't have a physical home,

260.text:
and our physical
sense of self, our bodies.

263.text:
And I feel that this separation
is dangerous and disempowering.

268.text:
I met with a new patient the other day:
she came in with her husband

272.text:
and both of them were terrified
of the changes in her body.

276.text:
Illness is, in many ways,
like a random act of violence.

281.text:
It is like returning to find your home
burgled and ransacked.

285.text:
The many personal symbols of your life
either lost or forever changed.

290.text:
Overnight, my patient's joints
had become swollen, stiff, and painful.

297.text:
She struggled to do the things
that she had done without thinking.

300.text:
She struggled to get out of bed,
to get dressed, to cut her food.

308.text:
I explained the diagnosis
and the treatment,

311.text:
which involves strong,
and sometimes toxic medications

314.text:
that she will probably need to take
for the rest of her life.

319.text:
My patient said, "Thank you very much
for all this information.

326.text:
What can I do, what can I do in my life
to get myself better again?"

334.text:
how she could clean up her ransacked home
and make it familiar again.

339.text:
Well, if I followed the dictums
of evidence based medicine,

343.text:
all I can offer her is the advice
of a healthy lifestyle,

348.text:
and the advice to take
the medications I had offered her.

353.text:
is that ultimately,
there is not much she can do.

357.text: She is a victim of her biology,

360.text:
and she must learn to live
in this new, damaged home.

363.text:
Violated first by illness,
and now by medication.

369.text:
is through tinkering
with pharmaceutical spanners,

371.text:
something that is entirely in my control,
and entirely out of hers.

377.text:
Her agency has efficiently
and effectively been removed.

382.text: I feel this is deeply wrong.

386.text:
In doing this, we separate
the person from their body.

390.text:
We drive a stake through their natural
sense of being in this world.

396.text: We do this justified by scientific truths.

400.text: But, is this the whole truth?

402.text:
One of the fallacies
of the scientific method

405.text:
is the publication of certain truths
and the casual shelving of others.

411.text:
Is it possible that we are doing this
on a grand scale

414.text:
by focusing on the mechanical
aspects of human nature

421.text: Are we really just biological machines,

424.text:
that once broken,
can only be fixed by drugs or surgery?

429.text:
Do we really have less control
over our biological homes

432.text: than we do our brick and mortar homes?

435.text:
And what about that aspect of life
that science continues to ignore

442.text: This rich, inner world of ours,

444.text:
the world of imagination,
and belief, hope, and fear?

449.text:
Is world of the mind
truly disconnected from the body?

454.text:
Well, this is what the scientific dogma
would have us believe,

457.text: but I feel it's time to challenge this.

460.text:
And I would like to walk us
through a little exercise.

463.text:
Just imagine
that you are waiting in the wings,

466.text:
somewhere over there in the dark,
waiting for your name to be called,

469.text:
so that you can walk out
onto this stage, this red spot here,

475.text:
Might this situation provoke
a change in your body?

478.text: Well, I can attest to the fact

480.text:
that there is quite a vigorous
physical change.

484.text:
are making me feel like my heart
is pumping up in my throat,

487.text:
my hands are cold and clammy,
my mouth is dry, I'm queasy.

491.text:
I think we've all been there
in one way or another.

494.text: But, what provoked this physical change?

497.text: It was a thought, wasn't it?

499.text: It was the thought of speaking in public,

502.text: a concept living entirely in my mind.

506.text:
The thought of public speaking
is the modern day equivalent

509.text:
of the thought of a saber-toothed tiger
hiding in the bushes.

512.text:
The fear primes the fight-or-flight
stress response

516.text:
which has evolved to increase
our chances of survival

518.text:
if there is an immediate
threat to our safety.

521.text: But here on this stage, on this red dot,

524.text:
there is no threat
to my safety, I don't think.

527.text:
There is a threat to my sense of self,
a threat to my fragile ego,

531.text: a concept that lives entirely in my mind.

534.text:
But my biology,
all these billions of cells,

537.text:
have responded
to this imaginative thought,

541.text: this complex perception of social risk.

545.text:
Today, here on this stage,
my mind has influenced my matter.

551.text: So there is a relationship, isn't there?

554.text:
It seems from this very simple
thought experiment

557.text:
that the mind serves as an intermediary
between the environment and our bodies.

562.text: And it makes sense, doesn't it?

564.text:
Something needs to process
the cues from the environment,

567.text: and then signal our body to act.

572.text:
this link between environment
and body was quite linear.

575.text: You might hear a rustle in the bushes,

577.text:
or see a flash of pale color
between leaves,

580.text:
equals risk, equals
be prepared to fight or flee.

583.text:
But now, millennia later,
our nervous systems must process

588.text:
a much more complex world
with a much more complex mind.

592.text:
But our biology still really
can't tell the difference

596.text:
between a nuanced social fear
like public speaking,

601.text:
It's all processed in the same way,
the same physiologic response,

604.text:
regardless of whether we truly
need to flee the scene,

609.text: survive on a red spot for some minutes.

614.text:
So, the fear of public speaking
is one on an endless list

618.text:
of modern day equivalents
of tigers hiding in bushes.

621.text:
From the threat of an unstable economy,
perhaps an abusive relationship,

626.text:
fear of job loss, and perhaps fears
and risks that aren't even rational,

635.text:
And as we spend each day worrying
about our own unique combination of fears,

639.text:
our bodies obligingly respond,
physically preparing us for the worst.

645.text:
Now, this becomes even more interesting
when you look at the scientific evidence,

652.text:
between psychological stress
and physical illness.

656.text:
We now know that illnesses
such as heart disease, diabetes,

661.text:
autoimmune disease, and infection,
are all linked to stress.

667.text:
There's also evidence
that your outlook on life matters.

672.text:
Whether you are
a glass half full kind of person,

675.text:
or a glass half empty kind of person,
will have an impact on your health.

679.text:
If you happen to view the world
through rose-colored lenses,

682.text:
you're actually more likely
to live longer,

684.text:
to be healthier,
and to overcome illness faster.

689.text:
During that conversation
with my patient the other day,

692.text:
she asked me how
she developed her arthritis.

696.text:
And I explained to her this link
between stress and illness.

700.text:
And as I spoke, she and her husband
exchanged looks.

703.text:
She told me that last year, her husband
had been diagnosed with cancer,

707.text: and her mother had passed away.

710.text: It had been a very difficult year.

713.text:
And it seemed clear to all of us
there in the room that day,

718.text:
between the outer world,
the inner world, and our bodies.

722.text:
It is not always separate,
as we have been taught to think.

729.text:
some of these ideas have crept
into conventional medicine.

733.text:
The NHS now prescribes
cognitive-behavioral therapy,

739.text:
as part of the treatment paradigm
for mental illness.

743.text:
Leading healthcare institutions
like the Mayo Clinic

746.text:
are recognizing that meditation
may be beneficial

748.text:
not just for mental health,
but for physical health as well.

753.text:
And Harvard University has set up
a center designed to harness

757.text:
the potential therapeutic benefits
of the placebo effect,

760.text: another piece of that mind-matter puzzle.

767.text:
if you use the words 'mind' and 'body'
together in one sentence,

771.text:
you are almost immediately
placed into the camp

773.text: of the quacks and the charlatans.

775.text:
So this is a conversation I've yet to have
with my medical colleagues.

780.text:
Medicine is holding fast
to the matter-based paradigm.

785.text:
And every day, I see the sense
of dislocation my patients feel,

789.text:
as we turn the microscope to the matter,
and ignore their deeper sense of self,

794.text:
and related perceptions,
beliefs, and fears.

800.text:
So, what needs to change?
And how can the healthcare system help?

806.text:
Well, we can't control
all the sources of stress out there,

809.text:
but we can help patients
modify their response to stress.

814.text:
We can do this by offering
cognitive-behavioral therapy,

819.text:
as part of the treatment paradigm
for all chronic illness,

822.text:
regardless of whether it's perceived
to be above the neck or below it.

828.text:
we would simply be modifying
a modifiable risk factor.

832.text:
We know that exercise,
and diet, and smoking

834.text: are risk factors that can be changed.

837.text:
Well, based on the scientific evidence,
stress resilience should be on that list.

844.text: But if we move our gaze away

846.text:
from the scientific
microscope for a moment

848.text: and look at the bigger picture,

850.text:
what else would we be doing
if we were to take this step?

854.text: If we were to recognize this link,

856.text:
this communication
between environment, mind, and body,

860.text:
this connection
between stress and illness,

863.text:
we would be doing something
much bigger than modifying a risk factor:

868.text:
we would be helping medicine
transcend the mechanical.

873.text:
We would be engaging
that part of ourselves

875.text:
that transforms us from biological
machines, to human beings.

881.text:
I would love to be able to tell
my patient with arthritis

884.text: that there is a lot that she can do.

887.text:
That her perception of,
and response to the world out there,

890.text: has an impact on her world in here.

893.text: And, this is something she can change.

897.text:
Responsibility is the ability
to make a response.

902.text: We would be giving people this ability,

905.text:
and we'd be returning to them
their sense of agency,

909.text: which we know is a critical ingredient

911.text:
of feeling whole, and uniquely,
and beautifully human in this world.

917.text:
Despite the prevailing world view
that draws a line

922.text: between the real world of matter

925.text:
and the ephemeral world
of the imagination,

927.text:
all around us is evidence
that life is not so cleanly dissected.

933.text:
And back to our old dichotomies
of science and art, matter and mind,

943.text:
well, we all inhabit
these dichotomies all day, every day.

950.text:
not necessarily in a world view
but in a basic truth:

957.text: we are the compilation of an interplay

960.text: between the known and the unknowable.

964.text:
And that, it is this alchemy
that enables us to live creative lives,

969.text:
to be heroes in our own stories,
both real and imagined.

974.text:
Two worlds that are not
so separate after all.

978.text:
They are, in fact, two facets
of this one beautiful jewel we call life.
